article:
The 'Cords of Billroth' (also known as 'splenic cords' or 'red pulp cords') are
found in the red pulp of the spleen between the sinusoids, consisting of fibrils
and connective tissue cells with a large population of monocytes and
macrophages. These cords contain half of the human body's monocytes as a reserve
so that after tissue injury these monocytes can move in and aid locally sourced
monocytes in wound healing. Swirski FK, Nahrendorf M, Etzrodt
M, Wildgruber M, Cortez-Retamozo V, Panizzi P, Figueiredo J-L, Kohler RH,
Chudnovskiy A, Waterman P, Aikawa E, Mempel TR, Libby P, Weissleder R, Pittet
MJ. (2009). Identification of Splenic Reservoir Monocytes and Their Deployment
to Inflammatory Sites. Science, 325: 612-616. PMID 19644120

Erythrocytes pass through the cords of Billroth before entering the sinusoids.
The passage into the sinusoids may be seen as a bottleneck, where erythrocytes
need to be flexible in order to pass through. In disorders of erythrocyte shape
and/or flexibility, such as hereditary spherocytosis, erythrocytes fail to pass
through and get phagocytosed, causing extravascular hemolysis.  Chapter 12, page 425 in: 8th edition.
